content.description:
This is a fun route that starts easy and gets progressively harder.  5.7 face moves lead to 5.8 and 5.9 as the route steepens.  Various thin cracks are present higher up.  There are only a few moves of 10a near the top.  The crux is somewhat height-dependent and a fun puzzle.

To descend, traverse climber's right to the two-bolt anchor at the top of The Right Hand of Light and rap.
content.protection: This climb can be led or Tr'd.  To lead, use thin to 2", but the anchor takes bigger pieces - up to 4".  To TR, you must first climb one of the easier routes on the north face (such as But Fear Itself) and traversing right to go around the corner to the West face.  The traverse is easy, but exposed - some may want to do it roped.
content.location: This route is on the left side of the West face of Lava Dome.  It is marked by several thin cracks going diagonally up and to the left in the upper half of the route and is directly below a large cleft between two boulders on top of the formation.

content.description: This is a challenging route that will reward careful inspection of all resources available!  The crux comes at the beginning and creative use of counter pressure and body position will be helpful.  Higher up the route is easier, but only by a letter grade or so.
content.location: This route is on the right side of the West face of Lava Dome.  It can easily be located by the bolted anchor at the top.  Start on the top of a big ledge to the right of Standing Ovation.  This ledge is most easily reached by scrambling from the right side of the formation.

content.description: The arete on the right side of the West Face.The route is somewhat runnout on dubious pro.

climbs.name: Nothing to Fear
climbs.fa: Troy Mayr, Steve Anderson, Ed Hunsaker & Amy Sharpless, February 1988

content.description:
This is the crack to the left of "But Fear It's Self".

It's a pretty good, steep 5.6. A bit rotten at the start, but the rock improves after a few moves.
Begin in the middle of the West Face. Steep face climb past 3 bolts on excellent, varnished rock.
content.protection: 3 bolts, then a #2 camalot and a horn tie-off protect a traverse right to a 2-bolt anchor.

content.description: 5 bolt face climb on West Face up nicely featured varnish.

Climb the crack system immediately to the right of

Hot Flashes

.

climbs.name: Kona
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Patty Kline, April 2003

content.description:
Begin on a slim ledge/ramp just right of

Mauna Kea

and climb the face (interspersed with horizontal seams) up to the last bolt on Mauna Kea.
A nice steep face climb on the north face of Lava Dome.  Really fun face climbing past 2 good bolts leads to easier face climbing past a seam up high.  Good but short.
content.protection: Two well located 3/8 bolts protect the crux, some small cams, nuts and micro-nuts for the top seam.  Tie-off blocks and flakes for belay or medium-big cams.
content.location:
Just right of

But Fear Itself

. Descend by walking southeast about a minute down to packs.

content.description: This is a cool route. It's steep and intimidating for the 5.8 leader, but once you're on it, nice footholds appear to the left of the crack.Pulling thru the steep crux, two-thirds up, is exciting and well protected with a large cam in the crack. The upper third, which looks like a hike from below, is interesting, too. Walk off the back.
content.protection: A #3.5 (4") Camalot was perfect to protect the crux.
